person_479.name: WilliamCoates
person_479.description: Member of a family of Bristol wine merchants, visitor to the Medical Pneumatic Institution, and subscriber to various Bristol literary works. Later detained in France following the end of the Peace of Amiens.

person_367.name: GeorgeHandel
person_367.description: German-born composer who spent much of his life in Britain, and was buried in Westminster Abbey.

person_082.name: Jean-JacquesRousseau
person_082.description: Swiss born French philosopher who wrote, among other things, on social inequality and education. His ideas were used widely during the French Revolution.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_032.name: FrancisHauksbee
person_032.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

person_726.name: JamesStodart
person_726.description: British surgical instrument maker; experimented on steel with Michael Faraday. FRSL.

person_329.name: Thomas (Tom)Wedgwood
person_329.description: Youngest son of Josiah Wedgwood who became a close friend of Davy's. Together they published a paper which has been taken as marking the start of chemical photography.

person_382.name: Joseph LouisProust
person_382.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_727.name: John BirdSumner
person_727.description: Teacher at Eton College; later Bishop of Chester and Archibishop of Canterbury. FRSL.

person_572.name: George O'BrienWyndham
person_572.description: From 1763 3rd Earl of Egremont. Very wealthy collector and agriculturalist who criticised some of Davy's work. FRSL.

person_321.name: GeorgeFordyce
person_321.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

person_044.name: ArthurYoung
person_044.description: Agricultural writer and Secretary to the Board of Agriculture. FRSL.

place_006.name: Penzance
place_006.description: Penzance is a town, civil parish, and port in the Penwith district of Cornwall, and Davy's birthplace.

place_122.name: Wales
place_122.description: Wales is a country in southwest Great Britain known for its rugged coastline, mountainous national parks, distinctive Welsh language and Celtic culture.

place_605.name: River Avon
place_605.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

place_518.name: Ganges
place_518.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_532.name: Galilee
place_532.description: Galilee is a region located in northern Israel and southern Lebanon.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_419.name: Mount's Bay
place_419.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

place_444.name: Tintern Abbey
place_444.description: Tintern Abbey is a ruin found on the banks of the River Wye in Monmouthshire, Wales. It was the location of a poem by William Wordsworth, published in Lyrical Ballads, the second edition of which was proof-read by Davy.

place_509.name: Lizard Point
place_509.description: The Lizard is a peninsula of the southern coast of Cornwall. It is the most southerly point of the British mainland. The geology of the Lizard is complex: it contains some of Cornwall's oldest (Precambrian) rocks, as well as heavily metamorphosed rocks.

place_520.name: Kynance Cove
place_520.description: Kynance Cove lies to the east of Mount's Bay in Cornwall, on the Lizard Peninsula.

place_525.name: Mullion, Cornwall
place_525.description: Mullion is a village on the Lizard Peninsula, Cornwall.

place_794.name: Gulval
place_794.description: A village in Cornwall, near Penzance.

place_1396.name: Bengal
place_1396.description: Bengal is a historical geographical, ethnolinguistic and cultural term referring to a region in the eastern part of the Indian subcontinent at the apex of the Bay of Bengal. The region of Bengal proper is divided between the modern-day sovereign nation of Bangladesh and the Indian state of West Bengal.

place_1397.name: Mumbai
place_1397.description: Mumbai (formerly called Bombay) is a densely populated city on India’s west coast.

otherwork_144.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society
otherwork_144.author: Humphry Davy
